title: Deep Audio Watermarks Are Shallow: Limitations of Post-Hoc Watermarking Techniques for Speech
author: Patrick O'Reilly (Northwestern University), Bryan Pardo (Northwestern University), Zeyu Jin (Adobe Research), Jiaqi Su (Adobe Research), ...
relevance_why: This paper explores the vulnerabilities of current audio watermarking techniques to transformations, which is highly relevant to my research in preserving audio quality and authenticity in speech generation.
background: Examining the effectiveness of audio watermarks in identifying synthetic speech when subjected to various transformations to assess their real-world applicability.
contribution: This paper introduces a comprehensive evaluation of audio watermarking methods under multiple transformations, achieving an understanding of their robustness and detecting weaknesses.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous approaches often assessed watermarking robustness against limited transformations, lacking a unified framework.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work expands evaluations by including a broader range of neural network-based transformations and a focus on speech audio.

key_innovation: The paper's approach reveals how easily current watermarking methods can be thwarted by low-bitrate audio codecs and denoisers, emphasizing the need for more resilient techniques.
real_world_impact: Identifying the shortcomings in watermarking techniques helps inform the development of more robust methods, impacting how synthetic audio is regulated and protected.
limitations: The focus on post-hoc watermarking could hinder insights into potential proactive watermarking strategies.

new_terms.post-hoc watermarking: **Post-hoc watermarking** refers to embedding watermarks in media after it has been created, typically by manipulating audio features without altering the audio generation process.
new_terms.low-bitrate codecs: **Low-bitrate codecs** are audio compression algorithms designed to reduce file size while maintaining perceptible audio quality, often discarding less critical information.
